APPLICATIONS

Applications of our centrifuge

  • Laboratory centrifuge machines are extensively used for separating and purifying molecular mixtures in liquid mediums based on density gradients, utilizing centrifugal acceleration to achieve efficient separation.

  • Cell culture centrifuges are employed for cell harvesting, removing cell debris, and pelleting cells.

  • Fixed-angle centrifuges are commonly utilized in laboratories for applications that require sample pelleting, as their design ensures efficient sedimentation of particles or cells at high centrifugal forces.

  • Large centrifuge machines are employed in various industrial and research settings, enabling the separation and processing of large volumes of samples, such as in bioprocessing, industrial-scale protein purification, and large-scale cell culture applications.

  • Centrifugation is instrumental in concentration-related processes, including plasmid DNA (pDNA) synthesis.

FAQs

What is centrifugation, and what are the advantages of our centrifuges?

"Centrifugation" is a technique that uses centrifugal force to separate components in a mixture based on their density differences, providing advantages such as enhanced separation efficiency, increased sample throughput, improved sample purity, and the ability to concentrate samples. Its versatility and scalability make it a valuable tool in various fields, including biology, chemistry, and pharmaceuticals.

How is centrifugation used in biology and microbiology research?

Centrifugation plays a crucial role in biology and microbiology research by facilitating the separation of cellular components, such as organelles and proteins, from complex mixtures, enabling the isolation and purification of specific biomolecules for further analysis, as well as the sedimentation and concentration of microbial cells for microbiological studies.

What factors should be considered when purchasing a centrifuge?

When purchasing a centrifuge, several factors should be considered, including the type of centrifuge suitable for your application and sample size, the desired speed and RCF, the versatility and rotor options available, ease of use and safety features, maintenance and service requirements, cost, speed regulation range, setting resolutions, display type, overall dimensions, centrifuge weight, and power consumption.

What types of laboratory centrifuges do we offer?

We offer a wide range of laboratory centrifuges, including benchtop centrifuges, high-speed centrifuges, and ultracentrifuges. Centrifuge functions in the laboratory are to separate components of a mixture based on their density gradients using centrifugal force, enabling efficient separation, purification, and concentration of samples. All these types of centrifuges can be used in pharma as valuable tools in drug manufacturing as they enable the separation of liquids with varying densities, a critical process in the production of pharmaceuticals.
